And I got trouble with my neck.
I think the wear and tear of my neck had a lot to do with bending all day, you know.
What about when they put you on the line? Did you find that tough?
It was tough in the beginning.

I tried to keep up as best I could.

No.

Yeah.
Yeah.

I think that's got a lot.
And my neck had never been right, you know.

I'd never come back right.

I think that had a lot to do with it.
And a lot of people suffered with deafness.

He went stone deaf in the end.

How do you think Hoover changed over the years?
Were there changing owners and things?
Oh, deteriorated.
When Hoover's was Hoover's, they were a marvellous firm.
We had all that we could ask for, you know, with the company.
Marvellous company. They agreed to equality with women straight away.
We had all our holidays plus extra holidays.
They pay was good.
But once the change over started, it started to go in decline
and they started taking a lot of privileges away.
Like the premium days that we were added for every five years,
they were taken away from us.
The section dues, we used to have lovely section dues.
Christmas dues.
Every section would have their own individual Christmas due.
The money would be given and you could go wherever you wanted to.
When Hoover's was added, well, all that was stopped.
They took the Christmas bonuses away.

The pay wasn't so good.
The rises wasn't there.
And every company that took over, it just deteriorated more and more.

So, can you tell me about this ring then?
My friend Barbara and I worked in Hoovers.
